issue.title: User Implementation
issue.body:
Should be able to have basic account access. 

The first auth-based actions could start with basic user profiles and having trees attributed to specific users. This feature would mostly likely manifest itself in the following routing changes:

- `/` - login to Treedoff
- `/:userid` -  profile of specific user
- `/:userid/:treeID` - traversal view of a user's tree.

@connorqmoore you said you had already begun looking into this using [passport.js](http://passportjs.org/) for the server side implementation of this, what research / insight have you gathered?

# Implemented Features
- [x] Login and Signup
- [x] Logout
- [ ] Dashboard-esque page for a user overview
- [ ] Attribution of trees to specific users

issue.title: Tree Visualization
issue.body:
If you look in the [Redux dev tools](https://github.com/zalmoxisus/redux-devtools-extension), you can get a visualization of the `tree` item in the store as follows:

![img_2412 png](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6868877/24690575/b0177f3e-199b-11e7-81f1-f9a3c3f67018.png)

We should have a page that does this. It is called **Tree**doff after all. I don't know how far we originally got with this, but I seem to remember that we attempted to use [the react-tree-graph](https://github.com/jpb12/react-tree-graph) library to try and visualize the tree structure.

issue.title: Outline Server Startup
Tree Visualization
issue.body:
![out](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6868877/25027993/cf93b1a4-207e-11e7-87d4-9592146a46a5.gif)

This PR begins to address #28.

I mostly adapted the implementation from [here](https://github.com/romseguy/d3-state-visualizer/tree/master/examples/react-tree), but this PR serves as a good template of how to mount D3 components to React Components in the newly implemented `<Tree />` component.

How should I style it so that it doesn't look like complete 💩 ?

issue.title: Linting
issue.body:
So we don't drive each other insane, I implemented `npm run lint` to run a linter and then any test we write in the future.

In order to do this automatically, I have configured Travis CI to automatically run the linter as a test whenever a PR is created or updated. This was we can tell at a glance if there is still work to be done.
